M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Plaintiff, Jessica Torres, brings this action against Defendant, Mark Thompson, for breach of the statutory and common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment pursuant to M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, arising from Defendant's failure to provide essential services, namely hot water, at Plaintiff’s rental unit located at 123 Maple Street, Brockton, Massachusetts.

M.G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to M.G.L. c. 218, § 19.

M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the events giving rise to this cause of action occurred in Brockton, Massachusetts, within the jurisdiction of this Court.

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979) – Establishing the breach of quiet enjoyment as interference with the use and enjoyment of the premises.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion is about breach of the implied warranty of habitability and when a tenant’s rent obligation abates; it does not analyze or define the separate doctrine of breach of quiet enjoyment. The court repeatedly frames the issue in terms of habitability, warranty, and rent abatement, not interference with use and enjoyment under a quiet enjoyment claim. Thus, citing this case for the general definition of breach of quiet enjoyment is inaccurate.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability. We must decide (1) whether a tenant must pay full rent without abatement when the landlord, acting without fault or bad faith, fails to maintain a dwelling in habitable condition and (2) whether the tenant’s obligation to pay full rent persists until the landlord has had a reasonable time to repair the defect.”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994) – Clarifying landlord responsibility for habitability standards.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case expressly narrows, rather than expands, landlord responsibility for habitability by holding that the implied warranty of habitability concerns only physical conditions and is not breached by failure to provide security or by criminal activity of third parties. While the opinion does discuss landlord responsibilities for tenant security under a statutory injunction mechanism (§§ 32C–32D) and the covenant of quiet enjoyment, it explicitly rejects using the warranty of habitability to impose broader security or habitability obligations. Therefore, it does not support a generalized proposition that it ‘clarifies landlord responsibility for habitability standards’ in an expansive sense; it clarifies that habitability does not extend to these security issues.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the implied warranty of habitability is concerned with the provision, maintenance, and repair of the physical facilities vital to the use of the leased premises, and is not breached solely by the presence on the premises of uninvited persons engaged in unlawful activities or by the failure to provide security services.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) – Emotional distress recoverable in breach of quiet enjoyment claims.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court expressly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “actual and consequential damages” for interference with quiet enjoyment to include personal injuries such as emotional distress, and treats Solomon’s emotional-distress injuries as within the scope of § 14. Although the separate $10,000 quiet-enjoyment verdict was vacated as duplicative, the court makes clear that emotional distress is a recoverable element of damages in a statutory quiet enjoyment claim, thereby supporting the proposition.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that tenants may recover ‘actual and consequential’ damages from landlords who have interfered with their quiet enjoyment of leased premises…. The combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages, therefore, suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery. In the present case, not only were Solomon’s injuries foreseeable, but the jury found specifically that Gem knew or should have known that if it permitted floods to occur, Solomon would suffer emotional harm. Therefore, Solomon’s claim for emotional distress was within the scope of § 14…”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.proposition: *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) – Statutory damages for breach of quiet enjoyment include three months’ rent or actual damages.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns breach of warranty of habitability and Chapter 93A (including emotional distress damages), not statutory damages for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court does not discuss the statutory damage formula of three months’ rent or actual damages for quiet enjoyment violations, nor does it set or interpret that measure. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about statutory damages for breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.relevant_excerpt: [Discussing c. 93A damages] “In 1979, in what appeared to be, ‘in part, a reaction to the restrictiveness of our holding in Baldassari ...,’ the Legislature amended § 9 (1), and deleted the ‘loss of money or property’ requirement. … Because severe emotional distress is a form of personal injury, … it would seem to follow that it also is compensable under § 9, if the injury is the product of a violation of G.L.c. 93A, § 2.” (Opinion at 864-865). (No discussion of statutory damages for quiet enjoyment appears.)

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) – Holding landlords liable for conditions interfering with tenant enjoyment.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that landlords can be liable (via breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment/constructive eviction) for conditions—here, severe noise from a lounge tenant—that substantially interfere with residential tenants’ enjoyment, where the landlord created the situation and had the right and ability to control the nuisance. The court explicitly rejects a strict intent requirement and a nonfeasance/malfeasance distinction, and affirms judgments relieving tenants of rent because the premises were not reasonably habitable due to the landlord‑controllable disturbance.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: "There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done... Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable."

*Armstrong v. Collella*, 393 Mass. 1008.proposition: *Armstrong v. Collella*, 393 Mass. 1008 (1984) – Clarifying landlord duty to maintain essential services.
*Armstrong v. Collella*, 393 Mass. 1008.case_name: McDonald's Restaurants of Massachusetts, Inc. v. Commissioner of Revenue
*Armstrong v. Collella*, 393 Mass. 1008.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Armstrong v. Collella does not address landlord-tenant law, essential services, or any duty of a landlord to maintain such services. Instead, the text concerns whether McDonald’s activities constitute manufacturing for tax purposes and relies on York Steak House Systems v. Commissioner of Revenue. Therefore, citing this case for a proposition about landlord duty to maintain essential services is inaccurate.
*Armstrong v. Collella*, 393 Mass. 1008.relevant_excerpt:
Despite McDonald’s argument that its cooking process and assembly of the constituent parts of its hamburger, chicken, and fish sandwiches and other food products is a species of manufacturing, the case is governed entirely by our decision in York Steak House Syss. v. Commissioner of Revenue, ante 424 *1009(1984), in which we held that the process by which commercial grade cuts of beef become restaurant-quality steaks was not manufacturing.
...
The decision of the board is affirmed.

So ordered.

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987) – Highlighting breach of quiet enjoyment for failures to repair essential utilities.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion addresses a landlord’s obligation to provide heat and hot water and holds that, under the State Sanitary Code, any transfer of that obligation to the tenant must be in a written agreement. However, the case does not analyze or decide a claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it link failures to repair or provide essential utilities to quiet enjoyment specifically. The discussion is framed in terms of regulatory compliance and habitability, not quiet enjoyment, so citing it for that specific proposition overstates its holding.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The tenant maintains that under the State Sanitary Code the landlord is not excused from his obligation to provide heat and hot water unless there is a writing transferring the obligation to the tenant. The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling ‘shall’ supply heat and hot water ‘except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.’ … The plain and unambiguous language of the regulation indicates that a writing is required when the obligation to provide heat and hot water is transferred to the tenant.”

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) – Establishing hot water as a necessity for habitability.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: This concurrence/dissent discusses an implied warranty of habitability tied to compliance with the State Sanitary Code, but it does not specifically identify ‘hot water’ as a necessity or separately analyze it as an essential component of habitability. The judge advocates basing the landlord’s obligations on minimum code standards generally, and criticizes the majority for creating a broader, undefined warranty, but nowhere states or holds that hot water in particular is a requisite element of habitability. Thus, this opinion does not directly support the narrow proposition that the case established hot water as a necessity for habitability.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “The Code, which has the force of law and applies throughout the Commonwealth, fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation. It does so in great detail and to an extent never before incorporated in any statute. It expressly provides that ‘[n]o person shall ... let to another for occupancy any dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit, for the purpose of living, sleeping, cooking, or eating therein, which does not comply’ with its provisions, and further provides a criminal penalty for violation of its provisions.”

*Lafayette Place Assocs. v. Boston Redev.raw_text: *Lafayette Place Assocs. v. Boston Redevelopment Auth.*, 427 Mass. 509 (1998)
*Lafayette Place Assocs. v. Boston Redev.proposition: *Lafayette Place Assocs. v. Boston Redevelopment Auth.*, 427 Mass. 509 (1998) – Discussing conditions that impair tenant enjoyment.
*Lafayette Place Assocs. v. Boston Redev.case_name: Lafayette Place Associates v. Boston Redevelopment Authority
*Lafayette Place Assocs. v. Boston Redev.support_reasoning: The opinion is a complex contract and governmental immunity case concerning an option to purchase redevelopment land and related bad-faith allegations. It does not address landlord–tenant law, leasehold interests, or any doctrine about conditions that impair a tenant’s use and enjoyment of leased premises. Nothing in the holding or reasoning discusses “conditions that impair tenant enjoyment,” so the case does not support that specific proposition.
